pullRequest.title: Fixed mongo db injection FP
pullRequest.bodyText:
This is an effort to fix one FP I encountered where the the plugin tries to inject {"[$ne]", "[$regex]", "[$gt]", "[$eq]"} to a JSON payload . It also tries to call setParameter() which does not work on JSON payloads.
For example the web app I tested used the following pay load
[{"name":"username","value":"admin"},{"name":"password","value":"pass"}]
(The web app would return  {"success":true} for a valid authentication attempt )
the plugin tries to append [$ne] to the name and make the value empty so the intended result is
[{"name":"username","value[$ne]":""},{"name":"password","value":"pass"}]
However set parameter does not work as expected and actual payload is
[{"name":"username","value":""},{"name":"password","value":"pass"}]
to which the server returns the response {"success":false} .
Therefore the first condition is valid now (  initial response != injected response )
Then the plugin tries to inject [$eq] and what it intends is
[{"name":"username","value[$eq]":"admin"},{"name":"password","value":"pass"}]
However the injected response is
[{"name":"username","value":"admin"},{"name":"password","value":"pass"}]
which is simillar to the initial request and the response is  {"success":true} which would make the second condition also true, therefore the plugin thinks a flaw is present.
However I think that since the plugin already does check for Json payloads and injects values correctly at a later stage , we can skip the phase ' injection attack to url-encoded query parameters' altogether and avoid FP's
